questions.question:
Consider the syntax directed definition shown below

\(\begin{array}{ll} S \rightarrow \mathbf{ id :=} E&\qquad \{gen(\mathbf{ id}.place = E.place;);\}\\ E \rightarrow E_1 + E_2 &\qquad \{t = newtemp();\\ &\qquad gen(t = E_1.place + E_2.place;);\\ &\qquad E.place = t;\}\\ E \rightarrow id&\qquad \{E.place = \mathbf{id}.place;\} \end{array} \)

Here, gen is a function that generates the output code, and newtemp is a function that returns the name of a new temporary variable on every call. Assume that ti's are the temporary variable names generated by newtemp. For the statement 'X:= Y + Z', the 3-address code sequence generated by this definition is

(GATE CSE 2003)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Consider the translation scheme shown below
S \(\rightarrow\) TR
R \(\rightarrow\)+ T {print ('+');}R | \(\epsilon \)
T \(\rightarrow\) num {print (num.val);}
Here num is a token that represents an integer and num. val represents the corresponding integer value. For an input string '9 + 5+ 2', this translation scheme will print

(GATE CSE 2003)

questions.question:

\(S\rightarrow iEtSS'|a \)
\(S'\rightarrow eS|\epsilon \)
\( E\rightarrow b\)
In the predictive parse table. M, of this grammar, the entries M[S',e] and M[S',$] respectively are

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
A.

In statically typed language, each variable in a program has a fixed type

B.

In un-typed languages, values do not have any types

C.

In dynamically typed languages, variables have no types

D.

In all statically typed languages, each variable in a program is associated with values of only a single type during the execution of the program
questions.correct_answer:
C.

In dynamically typed languages, variables have no types
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
In a bottom-up evaluation of a syntax directed definition, inherited attributes can

(GATE CSE 2003)
options:
B.

be evaluated if the definition is L-attributed

C.

be evaluated only if the definition has synthesized attributes
questions.correct_answer:
B.

be evaluated if the definition is L-attributed
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:

(GATE CSE 2003)

questions.question:
Dynamic linking can cause security concerns because

(GATE CSE 2002)
options:
B.

The path for searching dynamic libraries is not known till run time.

D.

Cryptographic procedures are not available for dynamic linking
questions.correct_answer:
B.

The path for searching dynamic libraries is not known till run time.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
In the C language

(GATE CSE 2002)
options:
A.

At most one activation record exists between the current activation record and the activation record for the main.

B.

The number of activation records between the current activation record and the activation record for the main depends on the actual function calling sequence.

C.

The visibility of global variables depends on the actual function calling sequence.

D.

Recursion requires the activation record for the recursive function to be saved on a different stack before the recursive fraction can be called.
questions.correct_answer:
B.

The number of activation records between the current activation record and the activation record for the main depends on the actual function calling sequence.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow
